diagrams.description: Computational Genomics evolved from early DNA sequencing to high-throughput analysis transforming biomedical research and healthcare. DNA structure discovered by Watson and Crick (1953) laid molecular biology foundations. Sanger sequencing method (1977) enabled first DNA sequences but remained low-throughput. The Human Genome Project launched (1990) aiming to sequence entire human genome. BLAST algorithm (1990) revolutionized sequence similarity searching. First bacterial genome sequenced (1995) demonstrating whole-genome capabilities. Human Genome Project completed draft (2001) after decade-long international collaboration. SNP databases and HapMap project (2002-2005) cataloged genetic variation. Next-generation sequencing commercialized (2005-2007) with Illumina and 454 platforms dramatically reducing costs. The 1000 Genomes Project (2008-2015) characterized human genetic diversity. ENCODE project (2012) mapped functional elements across the genome. CRISPR-Cas9 genome editing (2012) enabled precise genetic manipulation. Single-cell sequencing emerged (2014+) revealing cellular heterogeneity. Cancer genomics initiatives like TCGA generated comprehensive tumor datasets. AlphaFold (2020) solved protein structure prediction using AI. Today's computational genomics integrates long-read sequencing, spatial omics, AI-driven discovery, and population-scale biobanks.

timeline
    title Computational Genomics Evolution
    1953 : DNA Structure Discovery
         : Watson & Crick foundations
    1977 : Sanger Sequencing
         : First DNA sequencing method
    1990 : Human Genome Project & BLAST
         : Whole genome & similarity search
    1995 : First Bacterial Genome
         : Whole-genome demonstration
    2001 : Human Genome Draft
         : Decade collaboration completed
    2002-2005 : HapMap Project
              : Genetic variation catalog
    2005-2007 : NGS Commercialization
              : Illumina cost reduction
    2008-2015 : 1000 Genomes Project
              : Human diversity characterization
    2012 : ENCODE & CRISPR
         : Functional elements & editing
    2014+ : Single-Cell Sequencing
          : Cellular heterogeneity
    2020 : AlphaFold Breakthrough
         : AI protein structure prediction
    2020s : Long-Read & Spatial Omics
          : Multi-modal AI integration
